strategy: Standardize the input features using Min-Max scaling (range [0,1]) instead of z-score normalization. This ensures all features contribute equally during training, especially when features have vastly different scales, which is common in house attributes like area, price, and year built.

actions.action:
cat << 'ENDOFFILE' > train_and_predict.py
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import MinMaxScaler
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
import numpy as np

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Drop Id column from train and test (we'll add it back in submission)
train = train.drop('Id', axis=1)
test = test.drop('Id', axis=1)

# Separate features and target
X = train.drop('SalePrice', axis=1)
y = train['SalePrice']

# Handle missing values
for col in X.columns:
    if X[col].dtype == 'object':
        X[col] = X[col].fillna(X[col].mode()[0])
    else:
        X[col] = X[col].fillna(X[col].median())

for col in test.columns:
    if test[col].dtype == 'object':
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].mode()[0])
    else:
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].median())

# One-hot encode categorical variables
X = pd.get_dummies(X, drop_first=True)
test = pd.get_dummies(test, drop_first=True)

# Align test and train columns
X, test = X.align(test, join='left', axis=1)

# Standardize features using Min-Max scaling
scaler = MinMaxScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)
test_scaled = scaler.transform(test)

# Train model
model = RandomForestRegressor(n_estimators=100, random_state=42)
model.fit(X_scaled, y)

# Predict on test set
y_pred = model.predict(test_scaled)

# Create submission
submission = pd.DataFrame({
    'Id': test['Id'],
    'SalePrice': y_pred
})

# Save submission
submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)
ENDOFFILE

cat << 'ENDOFFILE' > train_and_predict.py
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import MinMaxScaler
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
import numpy as np

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Drop Id column from train and test (we'll add it back in submission)
train_id = train['Id']
test_id = test['Id']

# Separate features and target
X = train.drop('SalePrice', axis=1)
y = train['SalePrice']

# Handle missing values
for col in X.columns:
    if X[col].dtype == 'object':
        X[col] = X[col].fillna(X[col].mode()[0])
    else:
        X[col] = X[col].fillna(X[col].median())

for col in test.columns:
    if test[col].dtype == 'object':
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].mode()[0])
    else:
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].median())

# One-hot encode categorical variables
X = pd.get_dummies(X, drop_first=True)
test = pd.get_dummies(test, drop_first=True)

# Align test and train columns
X, test = X.align(test, join='left', axis=1)

# Standardize features using Min-Max scaling
scaler = MinMaxScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)
test_scaled = scaler.transform(test)

# Train model
model = RandomForestRegressor(n_estimators=100, random_state=42)
model.fit(X_scaled, y)

# Predict on test set
y_pred = model.predict(test_scaled)

# Create submission
submission = pd.DataFrame({
    'Id': test_id,
    'SalePrice': y_pred
})

# Save submission
submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)
ENDOFFILE
